articles.headline: 2 Gawker Editors Resign Over Article’s Removal
articles.snippet: The editors, Tommy Craggs and Max Read, cited the removal of an article about a married media executive who was said to have sought a gay escort in their decisions to resign.
articles.abstract: The editors, Tommy Craggs and Max Read, cited the removal of an article about a married media executive who was said to have sought a gay escort in their decisions to resign.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Gawker posted an article on Thursday night about a married male media executive’s futile attempt to hire a gay escort, it was hoping to create a scandal.

articles.headline: ISIS Leader Takes Steps to Ensure Group’s Survival
articles.snippet: In delegating authority, the Islamic State’s reclusive leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, has drawn lessons from the fates of other militant groups, intelligence officials say.
articles.abstract: In delegating authority, the Islamic State’s reclusive leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, has drawn lessons from the fates of other militant groups, intelligence officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State’s reclusive leader has empowered his inner circle of deputies as well as regional commanders in Syria and Iraq with wide-ranging authority, a plan to ensure that if he or other top figures are killed, the organization will quickly adapt and continue fighting, American and Iraqi intelligence officials say.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: In Chattanooga, a Young Man in a Downward Spiral
articles.snippet: Mohammod Abdulazeez’s past included drug abuse, mental illness and trouble keeping work. The authorities also found that he viewed material connected to Anwar al-Awlaki, the radical U.S.-born cleric.
articles.abstract: Mohammod Abdulazeez’s past included drug abuse, mental illness and trouble keeping work. The authorities also found that he viewed material connected to Anwar al-Awlaki, the radical U.S.-born cleric.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — The last time family members here saw Mohammod Abdulazeez was last Tuesday, but they did not worry about his absence because they thought he was heading back to the Nashville suburb where he had found steady work. He had even talked about a coming business trip. They dared to hope that he was putting his troubles behind him.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Alan Blinder, Eric Schmitt and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: The Wind and Sun Are Bringing the Shine Back to Buffalo
articles.snippet: The renewable-energy industry is turning a city that used to be a punch line in jokes about urban decline into a regional powerhouse and job magnet.
articles.abstract: The renewable-energy industry is turning a city that used to be a punch line in jokes about urban decline into a regional powerhouse and job magnet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Along a bend in the Buffalo River here, an enormous steel and concrete structure is rising, soon to house one of the country’s largest solar panel factories. Just to the south, in the rotting guts of the old Bethlehem Steel plant in Lackawanna, where a dozen wind turbines already harness the energy blowing off Lake Erie, workers are preparing to install a big new solar array.

articles.headline: Capitalist Soul Rises as Ho Chi Minh City Sheds Its Past
articles.snippet: As a magnet for the young, Saigon, as the city in Vietnam is still locally known, is a place of opportunity, fun and increasing affluence.
articles.abstract: As a magnet for the young, Saigon, as the city in Vietnam is still locally known, is a place of opportunity, fun and increasing affluence.
articles.lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Taking a puff from a hookah and a sip from her beer, Thuy Truong, a 29-year-old tech entrepreneur in a black cocktail dress, pondered the question: What were her thoughts on the 40th anniversary of the fall of Saigon?

articles.headline: New York Escalates Investigation Into Promontory Financial Group
articles.snippet: New York’s financial regulator will take depositions this week in its inquiry into the Promontory Financial Group for potential conflicts of interest.
articles.abstract: New York’s financial regulator will take depositions this week in its inquiry into the Promontory Financial Group for potential conflicts of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an executive at one of Wall Street’s top consulting firms testified before Congress two years ago, he stressed the importance of independence in reviewing bank misdeeds, declaring, “If we merely told our clients what they want to hear, we would lose credibility.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Uncertainty on Whether Cosby Revelations Could Hurt Him in Court
articles.snippet: Experts say a 2005 deposition in which Bill Cosby admits to philandering could be used against him, but they also point out that the burden of proof is high.
articles.abstract: Experts say a 2005 deposition in which Bill Cosby admits to philandering could be used against him, but they also point out that the burden of proof is high.
articles.lead_paragraph: New revelations about the sexual behavior of Bill Cosby have been greeted as a vindication to many of the women who have accused him of drugging and sexually assaulting them.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: When a Brief May Find a Real Friend on the Court
articles.snippet: Federal judges can rule on cases in which they have a stake in a company that files an amicus brief. But the appearance of impropriety raises questions.
articles.abstract: Federal judges can rule on cases in which they have a stake in a company that files an amicus brief. But the appearance of impropriety raises questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2013, Time Warner, the large media company, filed a brief urging the United States Supreme Court to rule against the online company Aereo, which was redistributing broadcast channels over the Internet.

articles.headline: ISIS Transforming Into Functioning State That Uses Terror as Tool
articles.snippet: The Islamic State is gaining a capacity to govern. But while the group still relies on brutality, its shift may have the West rethinking a military-first strategy.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State is gaining a capacity to govern. But while the group still relies on brutality, its shift may have the West rethinking a military-first strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Islamic State uses terror to force obedience and frighten enemies. It has seized territory, destroyed antiquities, slaughtered minorities, forced women into sexual slavery and turned children into killers.
